articles.headline: Fed Divisions Led to a Compromise on Interest Rates
articles.snippet: Debate over aid for the economy ended with the current low-interest-rate commitment, according to minutes from Aug. 9.
articles.abstract: Debate over aid for the economy ended with the current low-interest-rate commitment, according to minutes from Aug. 9.
articles.lead_paragraph: No one knows what to do to fix the economy.

articles.headline: Fancy Batteries in Electric Cars Pose Recycling Challenges
articles.snippet: The next big mother lode for salvage companies is expected to be the expensive, newfangled batteries powering electric cars. But automakers are divided over how to handle them.
articles.abstract: The next big mother lode for salvage companies is expected to be the expensive, newfangled batteries powering electric cars. But automakers are divided over how to handle them.
articles.lead_paragraph: HOBOKEN, BELGIUM — With fleets of electric cars starting to hit the roads, the next big mother lode for salvage companies is expected to be the expensive, newfangled batteries powering them.

articles.headline: Nevada Says Bank Broke Mortgage Settlement
articles.snippet: Nevada’s attorney general wants to end a broad mortgage agreement it struck with Bank of America in 2008.
articles.abstract: Nevada’s attorney general wants to end a broad mortgage agreement it struck with Bank of America in 2008.
articles.lead_paragraph: The attorney general of Nevada is accusing Bank of America of repeatedly violating a broad loan modification agreement it struck with state officials in October 2008 and is seeking to rip up the deal so that the state can proceed with a suit against the bank over allegations of deceptive lending, marketing and loan servicing practices.

articles.headline: Covering 2012, Youths on the Bus
articles.snippet: Once-coveted jobs covering the presidential campaigns are going to young journalists so news organizations can save money.
articles.abstract: Once-coveted jobs covering the presidential campaigns are going to young journalists so news organizations can save money.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A group of five fresh-faced reporters from National Journal and CBS News clicked away on their MacBooks one recent afternoon, dutifully taking notes as seasoned journalists from the campaign trail shared their rules of the road.

articles.headline: Tripoli Divided as Rebels Jostle to Fill Power Vacuum
articles.snippet: A week after rebels stormed Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi’s former stronghold, much remained divided into fiefs, each controlled by quasi-independent brigades.
articles.abstract: A week after rebels stormed Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi’s former stronghold, much remained divided into fiefs, each controlled by quasi-independent brigades.
articles.lead_paragraph: TRIPOLI, Libya — Fighters from the western mountain city of Zintan control the airport. The fighters from Misurata guard the central bank, the port and the prime minister’s office, where their graffiti has relabeled the historic plaza “Misurata Square.” Berbers from the mountain town Yafran took charge of the city’s central square, where they spray-painted “Yafran Revolutionaries.”
articles.byline: By David D. Kirkpatrick and Rod Nordland

articles.headline: As Refugees From Haiti Linger, Dominicans’ Good Will Fades
articles.snippet: As the post-quake good will between the Dominican Republic and Haiti has ebbed, Dominicans want quake refugees and recent economic migrants to go.
articles.abstract: As the post-quake good will between the Dominican Republic and Haiti has ebbed, Dominicans want quake refugees and recent economic migrants to go.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHENE, Dominican Republic — They have been blamed for spreading cholera, taking jobs and driving up crime, and now, with memories of the earthquake and the bonhomie it generated rapidly fading, this country is taking action: it is deporting Haitian refugees, turning them away from the border and generally making their lives difficult.

articles.headline: Via Zipcar, Ford Seeks Young Fans
articles.snippet: Ford Motor and Zipcar are expected to announce a partnership in which the automaker will supply its vehicles to Zipcar rental locations on 250 college and university campuses.
articles.abstract: Ford Motor and Zipcar are expected to announce a partnership in which the automaker will supply its vehicles to Zipcar rental locations on 250 college and university campuses.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT — It wasn’t long ago that car-sharing services like Zipcar were perceived as a threat to the sales volumes of traditional automakers.

articles.headline: Where Pay for Chiefs Outstrips U.S. Taxes
articles.snippet: The authors of a new study said their findings suggested that current United States business policy was rewarding tax avoidance rather than innovation.
articles.abstract: The authors of a new study said their findings suggested that current United States business policy was rewarding tax avoidance rather than innovation.
articles.lead_paragraph: At least 25 top United States companies paid more to their chief executives in 2010 than they did to the federal government in taxes, according to a study released on Wednesday.

articles.headline: India Measures Itself Against a China That Doesn’t Notice
articles.snippet: Measuring economic development against China seems to be a national obsession in India.
articles.abstract: Measuring economic development against China seems to be a national obsession in India.
articles.lead_paragraph: MUMBAI, India — It seems to be a national obsession in India: measuring the country’s economic development against China’s yardstick.
